what: The ilostat R package in a few words
title: Accessing ILOSTAT Data with Rilostat
text: R package provides tools access, download work data contained ILOSTAT, ILO Department Statistics’ online database. ILOSTAT’s data related metadata also directly available ILOSTAT’s website. information ILOSTAT’s R package, including contact details source code, refer github page.

title: Accessing ILOSTAT Data with Rilostat
text: ILO’s main online database, ILOSTAT, maintained Department Statistics, world’s largest repository labour market statistics. covers countries regions wide range labour-related topics, including employment, unemployment, wages, working time labour productivity, name . includes time series going back far 1938; annual, quarterly monthly labour statistics; country-level, regional global estimates; even projections main labour market indicators. ILOSTAT’s website provides immediate access data related metadata different ways. Basic users can simply view desired data online download Excel csv formats. advanced users can take advantage ILOSTAT’s well-structured bulk download facility (user guide). ilostat R package ('Rilostat') designed give data users ability access ILOSTAT database, search data, rearrange information needed, download desired format, make various data visualizations, programmatic replicable manner, possibility quickly re-running queries required.

title: Accessing ILOSTAT Data with Rilostat
text: Unless already know code indicator ref_area (reference area - countries regions) want download, first step search data interested . get_ilostat_toc() provides grep style searching available indicators ILOSTAT’s bulk download facility returns indicators matching query. get_ilostat_toc(segment = 'ref_area') returns datasets available ref_area (‘country’ ‘region’). access table contents available indicators ILOSTAT (indicator):  Table 1a. Extract, ‘Table contents indicator English’  settings available 3 official languages ILO: English ('en'), French ('fr') Spanish ('es'). default 'en'. instance, access table contents available datasets reference area ILOSTAT Spanish:   Table 1b. Extract, ‘Table contents ref_area Spanish’ can search words expressions within table contents listing ILOSTAT’s indicators. example, searching word “bargaining” return indicators containing word somewhere indicator information:  Table 1c. ‘Table contents indicator search word ’bargaining’’ Similarly, can also search list available datasets reference area given reference area (using country region name code) even given data frequency (annual, quarterly monthly). search also allows look several alternative /additional items . instance, look datasets annual data either Albania France:  Table 1d. ‘Table contents ref_area search words ’France’ ‘Albania’ ‘Annual’’ can also manipulate ILOSTAT’s table contents’ dataframe using basic R filter. already familiar ILOSTAT data way structured, can easily filter want. example, know beforehand want data ILOSTAT’s Short Term Indicators dataset (code “STI”) interested monthly data (code “M”) can simply :  Table 1e. Extract, ‘Table contents indicator filtered Monthly Short term indicators’
code: toc <- get_ilostat_toc( quiet = TRUE) toc <- get_ilostat_toc(segment = 'ref_area', lang = 'es', quiet = TRUE) toc <- get_ilostat_toc(search = 'bargaining', quiet = TRUE) toc <- get_ilostat_toc(segment = 'ref_area', search = c('France|Albania', 'Annual'),                                              fixed = FALSE, quiet = TRUE) toc <-  dplyr::filter(get_ilostat_toc(), collection == 'STI', freq == 'M', quiet = TRUE)

title: Accessing ILOSTAT Data with Rilostat
text: function get_ilostat() return time period information default raw time format (time_format = 'raw'), character vector following syntax: Yearly data: 'YYYY' YYYY year. Quarterly data: 'YYYYqQ' YYYY year Q quarter (number corresponding quarter 1 4). Monthly data: 'YYYYmMM' YYYY year MM month (number corresponding month 01 12). ease use data plotting time-series analysis techniques, function can also return POSIXct dates (using time_format = 'date') numeric dates (using time_format = 'num'). instance, following return quarterly unemployment data sex age, time dimension numeric format:  Table 3a. Extract, ‘Quarterly unemployment sex age’ following return monthly time-related underemployment data sex age, time dimension POSIXct date format:  Table 3b. Extract, Monthly time-related underemployment sex age
code: dat <- get_ilostat(id = 'UNE_TUNE_SEX_AGE_NB_Q', time_format = 'num', quiet = TRUE) ## Trying URL 'https://rplumber.ilo.org/files/indicator/UNE_TUNE_SEX_AGE_NB_Q.rds' dat <- get_ilostat(id = 'TRU_TTRU_SEX_AGE_NB_M', time_format = 'date', quiet = TRUE) ## Trying URL 'https://rplumber.ilo.org/files/indicator/TRU_TTRU_SEX_AGE_NB_M.rds'

title: Accessing ILOSTAT Data with Rilostat
text: function get_ilostat() stores cached data default file.path(tempdir(), "ilostat") rds binary format. However, via cache_dir arguments, also possible choose different work directory store data , via cache_format arguments can save formats, csv, dta, sav, sas7bdat. arguments can also set using options(ilostat_cache_dir = 'C:/temp') options(ilostat_cache_format = 'dta'). name cache file built using paste0(segment, "-", id, "-", type,"-",time_format, "-", last_toc_update ,paste0(".", cache_format)), ‘last_toc_update’ latest update dataset table contents. argument back = FALSE, datasets downloaded cached without returned R. quiet setting convenient particularly downloading large amounts data datasets.

title: Accessing ILOSTAT Data with Rilostat
text: Now found datasets needed filtered desired data, can start manipulating ILOSTAT data reproducible manner, even use favourite R packages make great data visualizations. example, can use ggplot2 dplyr visually compare trends male labour force participation rate Germany, France United States, since 2005 (see ). lineal graph allows us see male labour force participation rate considerably higher United States Germany France, decreasing steady pace since around 2008, closing gap participation rates particularly Germany, male labour force participation rate slightly increased last period observed.   can also build interesting (visually telling) stacked columns bars. example, based ILOSTAT data, can plot distribution employed persons economic class (defined according household’s per capita income/consumption per day). can even several disaggregations: example , chose show employment distribution economic class separately men women youth adults. figure, clearly understand working poverty (poor spite employed) affects youth much adults, women men.   can also combine ilostat package packages create triangular graphs, plotting three different indicators relate topic whose observations mutually exclusive. can use type graph, instance, visually convey share employed population working agriculture, industry services, three compared, even revealing, compare across countries. example , used three different indicators labour underutilization (unemployment, time-related underemployment discouraged job-seekers) study inter-related selected countries. three population groups mutually exclusive, part broad category labour underutilization. Unemployment represents persons employment, available employment actively seeking employment, discouraged job-seekers persons employment available employment actively look employment specific reasons situation labour market, time-related underemployment refers persons employment like work hours available work hours current working time. graph brings light differences across countries labour underutilization composition, showing unemployment biggest concern, opposed time-related underemployment discouragement.   also possible create maps showing indicators behave across world given point time (static maps) even time (dynamic maps allowing user scroll available time period). instance, built map see differences across world youth unemployment rate. , selected data compilation methodologically robust consistent across countries ensure international comparability: ILO modelled estimates (November 2017). can change legend settings use colour coding best suits data. case, colour scale used allows us quickly see youth unemployment rates particularly high Southern Northern Africa.

ref_area = c('FRA', 'USA', 'DEU'),                                sex = 'SEX_M',                               classif1 = 'AGE_AGGREGATE_TOTAL',                               timefrom = 2005, timeto = 2019), quiet = TRUE)  %>%    select(ref_area, time, obs_value) %>%    ggplot(aes(x = time, y = obs_value, colour = ref_area)) +    geom_line() +    ggtitle('Male labour force participation rate in 'AGE_YTHADULT_Y15-24' = 'Youth'),             classif2 =  factor(classif2) %>% recode_factor(                                 'CLA_ECOCLA_USDLT2' = '<US$1.9',                                  'CLA_ECOCLA_USDGE2LT3' = '>=US$1.9 & <US$3.2',                                  'CLA_ECOCLA_USDGE3LT5' = '>=US$3.2 & <US$5.5',                                  'CLA_ECOCLA_USDGE5' = '>=US$5.5')) %>% ggtitle("Employment by economic class, sex and age, South Africa, 1999") +     labs(x="Age group", y="Distribution of economic class (%)", fill="Economic class : ") +      theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +      scale_fill_brewer(type = "div") require(Rilostat) if(!require(tidyr)){install.packages('tidyr')} if(!require(dplyr)){install.packages('dplyr')} if(!require(plotrix)){install.packages('plotrix')} if(!require(stringr)){install.packages('stringr')}  triangle <- get_ilostat(id = c('EIP_WDIS_SEX_AGE_NB_A', %>%             label_ilostat() %>%             group_by(ref_area.label) %>%             mutate(obs_value = obs_value / sum(obs_value)) %>% ungroup() %>%             mutate(indicator.label = code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ ############# get simple dataset  dat <- get_ilostat("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A")  head(dat)  dat <- get_ilostat("NZL_Q", segment = "ref_area")  head(dat)   dir.create(file.path(tempdir(), "r_cache"))  dat <- get_ilostat("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A",                    cache_dir = file.path(tempdir(), "r_cache"))  head(dat)   clean_ilostat_cache(cache_dir = file.path(tempdir(), "r_cache"))    options(ilostat_update = TRUE)  dat <- get_ilostat("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A")  head(dat)  options(ilostat_update = FALSE)  options(ilostat_cache_dir = file.path(tempdir(), "r_cache"))  dat <- get_ilostat("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A")   clean_ilostat_cache()   ############# get multiple datasets  dat <- get_ilostat(c("CPI_ACPI_COI_RT_M", 'CPI_ACPI_COI_RT_Q'), cache = FALSE)  head(dat)  toc <- get_ilostat_toc(search = 'CPI_')  head(toc)  dat <- get_ilostat(toc, cache = FALSE) #id as a tibble  ############# get datasets with filters  dat <- get_ilostat(id = c("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A", 'EMP_2EMP_SEX_AGE_NB_A'),       filters = list(  ref_area = "FRA",       classif1 = "AGE_YTHADULT_YGE15",       time = "2016",      sex = c("T", 'SEX_F')), quiet = TRUE)  head(dat)  clean_ilostat_cache()   ############# store in other format  dir.create(file.path(tempdir(), "ilostat"))   dat <- get_ilostat("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A",                    cache_dir = file.path(tempdir(), "r_cache"), cache_format = 'csv')  dat <- get_ilostat("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A",                    cache_dir = file.path(tempdir(), "r_cache"), cache_format = 'dta')  ############# advanced manipulation   dat <- get_ilostat("UNE_2UNE_SEX_AGE_NB_A", cmd = "dat %>% count(ref_area)", quiet = TRUE)  label_ilostat(dat, code = 'ref_area')   clean_ilostat_cache() } # }
